Salome has sustained her business activities through 26 past loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of repairing and renovating her family home.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell

loans.name: Zikusooka Womens Group

texts.en:
56-year-old Zaituni believes the surest way not to fail in any business undertaking is to be determined to succeed. That has been this mother of 8's philosophy for the last 15 years as she goes about her clothing sales business in Lugazi. Her humility, confidence and the fact that she is always fresh as a daisy in dealing with her clients have been her winning stocks in trade. 

Zaituni has been succeeding by a long shot and she is hoping for more success in the near future. She says the inspiration to begin this business came from her dad. Prior to that, she was running a retail shop. On the side, Zaituni also does some small scale agriculture and tailoring. She says this business generates profits totaling 200,000 shillings per month. With the requested Kiva loan, she is going to purchase more clothing to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more clothing to resell

loans.name: Ruben Dario

texts.es:
Ruben Dario es un emprendedor que se ha rebuscado la forma de generar ingresos, pues de él depende su hijo al cual espera sacar adelante y ofrecerle un mejor futuro. Es así como desde hace año y medio decidió emprender un nuevo negocio, una tienda ubicada en el centro del municipio de Medellín en el departamento de Antioquia, donde trabaja con esmero para mejorar su ingresos y tener una mejor calidad de vida.

Ruben sueña con convertir su negocio en un minimercado, pero para ello es consciente que debe trabajar diariamente y esforzarse cada vez más; por ahora necesita de un préstamo para adecuar la fachada de su negocio y así posesionar el negocio dándole mejor presencia al establecimiento, logrando que sus clientes reconozcan y prefieran su microempresa por ser agradable, ofrecer gran variedad de productos y brindar un servicio amable y efectivo.
texts.en:
Rubén Darío is an entrepreneur who has sought out ways to generate income because he has a son that depends on him and he hopes to raise him and provide a better future for him.   This is how he’s been working for a year and a half in a new business: a store located in downtown Medellín, Antioquia Department, where he works with dedication to improve his income and to have a better quality of life.

Rubén dreams with converting his store into a minimarket but he’s aware that to do so he must work hard and try even harder each time.  For now, he needs a loan to furnish the façade of his store to provide it with an improved appearance to have better presence in the marketplace so that his customers will recognize him and prefer his micro business for being pleasant, for offering a great variety of products and for its kind and effective service.

loans.use: to furnish the locale his micro business is located in.

loans.name: Jolly

texts.en:
Jolly, who is a married mother of 2 children, started her retail shop and bar business 5 years ago and she earns 180,000 Uganda shillings per week as profits.The 35 year old lady explains that she gathered her capital from selling coffee, the activity she still carries on. Her children are 18 and 13 years of age and this hard working lady is happy to say that she has been able to send all of her children to school. 

Jolly has a dream of expanding her business and having a self reliant family, in terms of finances. With the Kiva loan, she plans to buy stock for the shop like sugar, soap, salt, beans and posho (porridge made of cassava) to increase her inventory to meet all the demands of her customers as well as to buy more beer and other drinks.

loans.use: to buy stock for the shop like sugar, soap, salt, beans, posho to increase her inventory to meet all the demands of her customers as well as to buy more beer and other drinks.

loans.name: Adripina

texts.es: Adripina tiene 56 años, convive con Alejo con quien tiene 1 hijo, ellos viven en su casa propia ubicada en la comunidad Teresa del distrito D. Pichari. Perseverante y trabajadora, así es Adripina, pero cuando era niña sus padres la obligaron que solo se dedicase a los estudios. Con el pasar del tiempo se dio cuenta que las carencias económica la empujaron a determinar y tener su propio negocio, desD. entonces posee una tienda D. abarrotes, actividad que lo viene realizando durante 4 años, y hasta el momento le está yendo muy bien. Paralelo a ello, cultiva cacao, pero en pequeñas escalas D. terreno. Generalmente trabaja sola, pero en ocasiones recibe la ayuda D. su esposo, quien se encarga D. vender lo cosechado en el local central D. su comunidad.  En el futuro espera comprar terrenos para  cultivar diferentes productos y en grandes extensiones. Este es su segundo crédito con MFP por lo que Adripina una vez más se compromete en pagar sus cuotas. Adripina está contenta con los integrantes D. su banco comunal porque todos son puntuales. Con los 2000 soles que solicita, comprará variados productos para implementar su tienda.
texts.en: Adripina is 56 years old and she lives with her common-law husband Alejo, with whom she has 1 child. They live in a house of their own located in the community of Teresa in the district of Pichari. Adripina is perseverant and hardworking but when she was young her parents asked her to only attend to her studies. With the passage of time she noticed the lack of financial resources and this pushed her to make a decision to have her own business. Since then she has had a grocery store. She has been in business for 4 years and to date it has done very well. Additionally, she also cultivates cocoa but in small plots of land. Generally she works alone but at times she receives help from her husband who takes charge of selling the harvest in the central market of their community. IN the future she hopes to purchase farm land where to cultivate different products and in large quantities. This is her second loan with MFP (Kiva Field Partner) and Adripina is once again committed to making her payments. Adripina is happy with the members of her communal group because they are punctual. With the 2000 soles that she requests will purchase various products to supply her store.

loans.use: to purchase products to supply her grocery store.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is 47 years old and married to a farmer. She is engaged in the buying and selling of fruits and vegetables. She sells bananas and string beans. They have a little plantation where her husband plants bananas and vegetables, while she is responsible for selling in the market and house-to-house in the harvesting season.
     
She is requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos (P) to buy string beans, eggplants and onions as additional vegetables to plant in their land. She has five children, and three of them are studying. Two of the children are helping financially through planting vegetables in their land. 

She is earning P5,000 each month, but it's not enough for them, so she budgets wisely to avoid lack of allowances and expenses of her school-aged children.

loans.use: to buy string beans, eggplants and onions as additional vegetables to plant.

loans.name: Chipenyo

texts.en:
Chipenyo is a married woman with four children. Three of her children attend school, while two are still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, she has operated a charcoal-selling business. Specifically, she sells charcoal from her home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge due to the high cost of transportation in her business. Her dream is to establish a wholesale business of charcoal-selling in the future.

She is requesting a loan in the amount of 80,000 KES to start a motorcycle business by purchasing a motorcycle. She decided to join Yehu so that she could have greater access to loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To start a motorcycle business by purchasing a motorcycle.

loans.name: Marciana

texts.en:
Marciana is 65 years old and married with three children. Marciana works very hard to provide for them. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Marciana has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as snack foods, detergent and groceries. 

In the future Marciana would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
This is Rose, 44, a resident of Dasmarinas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Sonny, a driver, and a mother to her four children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to save for her children's future.

Rose operates a community pharmacy store. She retails basic medicine and vitamins to the community. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from this she also sells mineral water for added income. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan for 16,000 PHP. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional stocks of medicine and mineral water to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Rose hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all of her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of medicine and mineral water needed in her business

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
Visitacion is married to Roberto and the couple was gifted with five children: Joji, 30 years old; Pampi, 27 years old; Kenneth Ian, 25 years old; Roberto Jr., 22 years old, and Nińo, 20 years old. Her children are all high school graduates. Visitacion is in the business of buying and selling fruits and vegetables in her village. She wakes up early every morning to buy vegetables in the market and then sell them in her village at retail price. 

Visitacion is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan to buy more goods such as cabbage, tomatoes, and beans, to increase her income. She hopes that her request will be granted and her loan will help her business grow.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Aggrey

texts.en: Aggrey is married and blessed with two children.  He has been operating a motorbike transport business for the last one year to support his family.  He has been able to retain his business because of his good reputation with his customers. He has employed two people to help him manage the business. In the next 5 years, he wants to expand his business. With 40,000 Kenyan shillings, he wants to buy motorbike spare parts.

loans.use: buy motorbike spare parts

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.es:
Gabriel de 22 años de edad, es soltero, vive con sus padres en su casa, cuenta con servicio de agua y luz, ubicada en el distrito de Chepén que pertenece al departamento de La Libertad.  Los pobladores de ésta zona se dedican a la agricultura, ganadería y turismo.

Gabriel maneja su propia mototaxi (transporte que se utiliza para movilizarse en distancias cortas, con un cupo máximo de 3 personas) desde hace un año aproximadamente, está actividad lo realiza en la misma zona donde vive, a pesar de la competencia en el mismo trabajo, él trata en lo posible, desde muy temprano movilizar una buena cantidad de pasajeros a sus diferentes destinos, y así pueda tener mayor cantidad de ingresos para solventar sus gastos y necesidades personales.

El crédito que ha solicitado a Edpyme Alternativa es de 1500 nuevos soles y su destino será para el mantenimiento de su mototaxi y cubrir algunos gastos de casa.  Gabriel es una persona responsable y trabajadora  que lo único que desea es seguir ayudando a sus padres económicamente.
texts.en:
Gabriel is 22 years old and single. He lives with his parents in their home which has water and electricity. They live in the Chepén district which is in the department of La Libertad. The locals there work in agriculture, livestock, and tourism. 

For about one year, Gabriel has driven his own moto-taxi (transport that is used to go short distances, with a maximum capacity of three people). He runs this business in the same area where he lives.  Despite job competition, he tries his best from very early in the day taking a good number of passengers to various destinations. This way he can have more income to cover his expenses and personal needs. 

The loan he’s asked Edpyme Alternativa for is 1500 nuevos soles. It will be used for maintenance of his moto-taxi and for some household costs. Gabriel is a responsible and hardworking person who only wants to continue supporting his parents financially.

loans.use: to do maintenance work on his moto-taxi and to cover some household costs.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is 34 years old and a mixed crop farmer. She is a single mother of a two-year-old child. She has been in the farming business for the past ten years with the monthly income of KES 8,000 which she uses to support her family.


She is applying for her first loan with KADET LTD after being introduced by a KADET staff member. Flora will use the loan to buy seedlings and farm manure for her farm. 

With the anticipated profit from the business she will venture into greengrocer business. Her hopes are to open a retail shop which will increase her income and educate her child.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and farm manure for her farm.

loans.name: El Tesoro 1, 2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Negra is a very hardworking woman who is dedicated to the door-to-door business of selling underwear and cosmetic products. She is the coordinator of this group called El Tesoro 1, 2 & 3 (The Treasure). They are located in one of the rural communities from San Pedro de Macoris that surround sugarcane fields, known as 'Bateyes.' She is the mother of two children (adult age). They are living separate from her simple home, which she shares with her long-term partner.  

Negra is receiving her sixth loan with Esperanza International after having successfully paid all her previous loans. She started her business with her firS. loan with Esperanza three years ago. She will use this loan to purchase underwear and cosmetic products for her business. She will reinveS. her profits in her business because Christmas season is coming and all the businesses have better sales. Also she will save and try to get some of the things she needs. 

Thanks for supporting this group of entrepreneurs!

loans.use: To buy underwear and cosmetic products to sell door-to-door

loans.name: Seily Ivonett

texts.es: La señora Sely es una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora quien se dedica al comercio de comida. Este negocio lo inicio hace 15 años y poco a poco lo ha ido mejorando ahora cuenta con seis trabajadores y vende más. Ella con el crédito comprara granos básicos (arroz, frijoles, aceite) carne, pollo, verduras, leña…etc.
texts.en: Sely is a hardworking entrepreneurial woman who sells food.  She started this business 15 years ago and has been improving it little by little.  She now has six employees and her sales have increased.  She will use the money from this loan to buy basic grains (rice, beans, cooking oil), meat, chicken, vegetables, firewood, etc.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her business.

loans.name: Martalina

texts.es:
Martalina, necesita invertir nuevamente en el negocio, por eso se decide a comprar 4 cerdos, para engordarlos, aumentando su granja y la posibilidad de generar mejores ventas.
Ella a través de los prestamos ha logrado cambiar la condición económica y que su granja ahora en mayor y le da más mantenimiento.
texts.en:
Martalina needs to invest in her business again, so she decided to buy four pigs to fatten, expanding her farming business and increasing the possibility of generating more sales.

Through the loans she has succeeded in changing her economic condition and enlarging her farm and giving it more maintenance.

loans.use: to buy four pigs.

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Angel Maria Group

texts.es:
Las mujeres del presente comité son de la oficina de Caacupé. Las señoras están en el segundo ciclo del programa de mujeres emprendedoras de la fundación y tiene 12 integrantes. Las integrantes del grupo son mujeres muy trabajadoras y luchadoras, que al máximo se esfuerzan por darle a sus familias lo mejor.
Una de las miembros es la señora Luciana, quien es una señora muy trabajadora, y emprendedora, ella por medio de su negocio puede cubrir los gastos que diariamente surgen. Nos comenta que tiene una heladería muy exitosa, ya que siempre tiene muchas ventas, en especial en el tiempo de calor. Uno de sueños es poder ampliar su negocio para poder seguir creciendo en lo comercial.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de helados de variados sabores, para que pueda tener un buen stock, y de esa forma poder estar preparada para la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
The women of this existing committee are from the office in Caacupé. They are participating in their second loan with the Women Entrepreneurs Program of Fundación Paraguaya. The group has 12 members. They are hardworking and determined women who want to maximize their efforts so that they can provide the best for their families.

One of the members is Sra. Luciana. She is a hardworking and enterprising woman. Through her business, she is able to provide for her daily expenses. She says that she has a successful ice cream business since she is always generating many sales, especially when the weather is warm. One of her dreams is to expand her business so that she can continue growing in the marketplace.

Luciana is requesting a loan to buy ice cream in different flavors so that she will have sufficient inventory. This will allow her to be prepared for the demands of her customers.

loans.use: to buy ice cream of various flavors.

loans.name: Abel David

texts.es:
Abel, vive con su esposa y una hija, él se dedica a la reparación y venta de celulares, usados y nuevos, este negocio nace por la necesidad de mantener para su familia una fuente de ingresos, él aprendió de  un amigo.
Actualmente está solicitando un préstamo para la compra de instrumentos para la reparación de celulares, desarmadores de diferentes medidas, también repuestos para celulares, con este préstamo obtendrá lo necesario para su negocio, ya que así podrá también resolver las necesidades de los clientes. 
Su sueño es que la familia viva mejor, con su negocio y con la inversión que realizara de este préstamo.
texts.en:
Abel lives with his wife and a daughter.  He has a business repairing and selling used and new cellular phones.  He started up this business in order to support his family and have a source of income.  He learned this trade from a friend.

Now he is requesting a loan to buy tools to repair cellular phones including different sized screwdrivers, and spare parts for cellular phones.  With this loan, he will be able to get what he needs for his business and will also be able to meet the needs of his customers.

His dream is to have his family live better because of his business and the investment that he is making now with this loan.

loans.use: to buy tools and accessories for cellular phones

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 40 years old and from Nakuru. He is married to Catherine, and they are blessed with one child who is three years old.

He has been running his business, which includes poultry farming, dairy farming, and a general shop, for the last two years. He has applied for his first loan of 100,000 KES from VisionFund Kenya to purchase a chicken incubator.

His monthly income right now is 25,000 KES. He has plans of using the anticipated profits from his expanded business to educate his child and to pay his loan back to VisionFund Kenya. In the future, he hopes to be a successful businessman.

loans.use: to buy a chicken incubator so that he can raise more chickens

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina is 46 years old, married with 2 children and from Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. To make a living, Gina manages a banana production business. She has been in this business for many years and earns 12,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2010, Gina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 28,000 PHP, which will be used to buy farm chemicals pesticides and fertilizer. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase farm chemicals use.

loans.name: Hodo

texts.en:
Hodo A. is an orphan and the eldest in her family of 12 children. She had to quit school early on, so that she could train as a cook. For two years, she has been actively looking for a way to get established and to put her high-potential cooking skills into practice.

With a loan of $950, Miss A. would better equip herself for broader benefit. Her strategy will consist of going public to provide less expensive hotel-style meals featuring both European and African cuisine. Her availability will be an asset for preparing special order meals and preferred dishes, as well as for the catering of celebrations, funerals, and other gatherings. And the energy and ingenuity of this young girl are just what is needed for the success of her plans. She will name her business «Restaurant Joy».

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Mademoiselle A. Hodo est une fille orpheline et aînée d’une famille de douze (12) enfants. Elle dû très tôt abandonner ses études pour apprendre le métier de cuisine. Voici depuis deux ans qu’elle est dans la vie active cherchant un moyen pour s’installer et exercer son activité qui est très porteuse.

Avec une somme d’un montant de $950, elle peut mieux s’équiper pour une meilleure prestation à la population. Sa stratégie consistera à mettre à portée de la population, des repas d’hôtel à moindre coût ; des mets européens et africains. Sa disponibilité sera un atout pour des services sur commande, repas préférentiel, fêtes, décès et autres manifestations. Le dynamisme et l’habileté de cette jeune fille constituent autant d’atouts pour le succès de son projet.

loans.use: Acquire equipment for food preparation

loans.name: Maria Otilia

texts.en:
My name is Maria S. and I have dedicated myself to the sale of all types of undergarments for men, women and children for the past four years. My clients are excellent; they like the quality of my product and, above all, the price. My goal is to increase my inventory so I can have more sales, and with the extra earnings I can remodel my house and put in a little shop with shelfs and a display window and run my business from there. The money will also help me feed my family.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi nombre es Maria S. me dedico a la venta de todo tipo de ropa interior para dama, caballero y niños, tengo mi negocio hace 4 años, mis clientes son excelentes ya que les gusta la calidad de mi producto y sobre todo el precio de venta. mi meta es increntar mis inventarios para tener una mayor venta y con las ganancias que obtenga poder remodelar mi casa de habitacion para hacer una pequeña tienda para vender mi producto, comprar una vitrina y estantes, tambien alimentar mi familia.

loans.use: Buy undergarments for men, women and children.

loans.name: Loan

texts.en: Mrs. Loan, 34, is married to Toan, 36 years old. They have a daughter and a son aged 7 and 15, wH. are students at high school and primary school. Mrs. Loan is a tailor in her village. She hopes to get a loan of $75 from the Kiva program so that she can update her knowledge of new mode style by catalogue, and purchase materials for making clothes in order to get more customers. Her family income is currently $7 per person/month. She will repay the loan monthly.

loans.use: To operate the small tailor shop.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 60 years old. She has 8 children. 4 of her children are in secondary school while 1 is studying in a local University. Esther is the oldest member of Olkiret women group and has been a good advisor of the young mothers. Esther encourages the young women to work hard. She advocates for group discipline and sets a good example by keeping to the group rules. She too is involved with the communal projects of tree planting and water harvesting. Esther’s group has come up with a plan of buying steers for sale. This is what Esther had to say…” It’s a good thing that the group has assessed the members needs. Since we have enough grazing land, the steers will not go hungry. After selling off the steers, my profit will assist my family with the education fees.” Esther has applied for USD 750 to purchase 6 steers. The repayment will be made in lump sum after 8 months.

loans.use: Esther intends to buy steers

loans.name: Moa

texts.en: Mrs. Moa S., 42, lives with her husband, 44, and their two children in the Kampong Cham district of Cambodia. Moa S. herself is a tailor, earning US$2 a day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, also earning US$2 a day. Their two children are currently employed at a garment factory. Mrs. S. intends to use the loan of US$1,000 to purchase beauty products that her children could sell to their co-workers at the factory, thereby increasing the family's earnings.

loans.use: Purchase of beauty products for sale

loans.name: Sofia

texts.es:
Sra. Sofia has belonged to the "Vecinas Unidas" (Neighbors United) community bank for 5 years. She lives in the Peruvian region or "departamento" of Ucayali. She is 48 years old and the mother of 1 son. Her husband works on the service staff at a local school. Sofia earns a living running a small food and drinks business at the entrance to another school.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.1,000 (1,000 Peruvian soles or about US$333), to be repaid in 4 months, Sofia will be able to add new items for sale, like cookies and candy, as well as a display case to better show off her products.

Sofia is pleased that she can provide for her family's basic needs and that her household can continue to do better and better.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Sofía pertenece al Banco Comunal “Vecinas Unidas” desde hace 5 años, su vivienda esta ubicada en el Jr. Morona 144 del Distrito de Callería del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 48 años y es madre de 1 hijo, su esposo trabaja en un colegio como personal de servicio. En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeño negocio de venta de frutas, comida y bebidas, en la puerta de un colegio.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.1,000 (US$ 333.00 aprox.), que lo pagará en 4 meses, podrá implementar su negocio con dulces, golosinas y una vitrina para una mejor presentación de sus productos.

Sofia se siente contenta de poder satisfacer sus necesidades primordiales y asi poder sentirse realizada al poder aportar para el desarrollo de su hogar.

loans.use: Buy a display case and new products for food business.

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
Marcela is a producer of cow's milk and is also a small potato and chuño farmer, products which she markets in the city of La Paz. Her husband is a builder and the main family income comes from both activities, which help to care for Marcela's two sons and mother. She lives in the Ninachiri-Laja community, an hour and a half outside the city of La Paz. The loan which she is requesting will be used to buy an average breed cow in order to increase milk production, and therefore improving the family income.

It is her first loan with Impro; the evaluation which has been carried has proven that her request for a loan is viable.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer.

Marcela es productora de leche de vaca y pequeña agricultora de papa y chuño, los mismos que comercializa en la ciudad de La Paz; el esposo es albañil y los ingresos principales de la familia se derivan de ambas actividades; con los que mantiene a sus dos hijos y madre. Vive en la Comunidad de Ninachiri - Laja (A una hora y media de la ciudad de La Paz). El crédito que ahora solicita será destinado para la compra de una vaca de raza mediana para incrementar la producción de leche y así poder mejorar sus ingresos.

Es el primer crédito con Impro; la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: To purchase of a dairy cow

loans.name: Kawaala 1B(C) Group

texts.en:
Fiona is 28 years old and married with four children. She owns a retail shop and would like to expand the inventory. With the extra profit, she wants to build a home for her family.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase stock in her retail shop

loans.name: Ruth Viviana's Group

texts.en:
Ruth and Maria have been members of the “Triunfo” community bank for four months. In the community bank, they have learned values, such as saving and working together. They commented that they feel united and know they have support within the bank.

Ruth is 21 years old. She lives with her partner and is expecting her first child. Ruth has been selling clothing for eight months. She travels nine hours to the city of Lima to sell the clothing to her friends and family.

Maria is 36 years old. She is a widow and has two children, who are ages eight and eleven. Maria sells a variety of seasonal products. For example, during the festival season, she sells face paint and decorations. Now she is planning to travel to Lima to buy school supplies to prepare for the school season.

Ruth and Maria need loans of 400 and 1000 soles respectively, which they will invest in buying shirts, pants, paint, pens, pencils, and notebooks.

One of the key aspects of the community bank is the interest-earning savings account each associate has. Ruth and Maria plan to use their savings to improve their business, study a specialty, and buy a house. Their dreams are to eventually finish their own studies, pay for their children’s education, and hope that their businesses will continue to grow.

loans.use: Ruth and Maria need loans of 400 and 1000 soles respectively, which they will invest in buying shirts, pants, paint, pens, pencils, and notebooks.

loans.name: Jhem

texts.en: Mrs. Jhem T., 49, sells vegetables in a busy market making about $1 a day. Her husband stays at home, growing a variety of vegetables on a plot of land that earns about $3 a day. They have eight children: three are garment workers, and two sons work as security guards in Phnom Penh with a salary $60 each per month. Three of the other children stay at home and help the father with his farming. He wants a loan from Kiva to hire people to dig an irrigation system, to make watering more efficient, especially during droughts. Moreover, this money will be used to purchase fertilizers to help grow vegetables.

loans.use: To dig an irrigation system and purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Heourn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Heourn S., 33, is the group leader of a group of four members in Au Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a grocer in the village and she doesn’t have any children. Her husband, Lor Kouk, is a driver who drives a motorbike with a cart and can generate a very small income to help meet the needs of his family.

Mrs. Heourn S.’s business faces an obstacle: many villagers buy her groceries on credit. Therefore, she doesn’t have capital to invest in her business. At the moment, her husband's cart needs to be repaired, and she doesn’t have money, so she decided to apply for a loan to fix the cart.

loans.use: To fix her husband's motorcycle cart

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: A. Mabel is 38 years old and married with a child. She is from Edo State, Nigeria. She started her own business and has sold provisions and drinks since 2007. Now, she needs a loan of $450 to buy more provisions and drinks to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy drinks and provisions for sale

loans.name: Adela

texts.es:
ADELA is a noble woman who works producing Andean products such as potatoes, corn, peas and other vegetables from her area to then transports them to distant cities where there is greater demand and therefore improves the earnings from her work. It is with these perspectives that she works all season and based on her effort she has gained the respect of her neighbors for her example of commitment and dedication. One of her wishes is to offer a quality education to her children who are in higher education in a city near to their community. It is for them that she seeks to improve her income and requests your support to increase the quality and quantity of her products.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva volunteer.

ADELA, es una noble mujer que se dedica a la producción de productos andinos como papa, maíz, arveja y demás netos de su zona para luego trasportarlos a las ciudades alejadas donde la demanda sea mayor a la de su zona y así adquirir mayores ganancias de su trabajo.Es con estas perspectivas que trabaja toda una temporada y basado en esfuerzo se ha ganado el respeto de sus vecinos por su ejemplo de constancia y dedicación. Y uno de sus deseos es brindarles educación de calidad a sus hijos quienes cursan estudios superiores en una cuidad cercana a su localidad, es por ellos que pretende mejorar sus ingresos económicos y solicita vuestra ayuda para incrementar la calidad y cantidad de sus productos.

loans.use: Injection of capital to increase the quality and quantity of her products

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
For four years Maribel has taken orders for clothing from her customers. She buys the clothes wholesale and then sells them to her neighbours who might request clothes, blankets, sneakers etc. It was her sister who encouraged her to start this business. Maribel also lends money to her neighbours.

Beforehand Maribel used to work as a domestic servant, but because she had to look after her own daughters, she quit this job. The loan requested is to be used to buy clothing for her customers. Maribel would like to open a clothing store in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva volunteer.

Maribel desde hace 4 años se dedica a la venta de ropa por pedidos. Ella compra la ropa por mayor y luego la vende a sus vecinos, quienes le solicitan ropa, frazadas, zapatillas entre otras cosas. Fue su hermana quien le animó a incursionar en este negocio. También hace préstamos de dinero a sus vecinos.

Maribel antes se dedicaba a trabajar como empleada doméstica, pero debido a que tenía que cuidar a sus hijas, dejó esta labor. Los préstamos que ha solicitado le han servido para invertir en la ropa que le piden. A Maribel le gustaría poner una tienda de ropa en su casa.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Joana

texts.en:
Joana M. is forty two years old. She has four children and is separated from her husband. The children are in school. 

Joana enjoys selling and she is motivated to work hard because she dreams of a better future for her children. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, and skimmed powdered milk. However, she is constrained from meaningful progress by a lack of capital. 

She is requesting a loan to buy more rice, sugar, vegetable oil, and body and hair creams to increase her profits. She believes the loan will enable her to realize her dream. She is a member of the community group called Halleluya Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and assist one another to repay their loans. 

Joana appears in the photo with one of her children.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Salha

texts.en:
Salha is 25 years old. She is married with one child who is 5 years old. She has been a charcoal and firewood seller since 2007. Everyday she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Salha now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Hum Yort's Group

texts.en:
The group loan consists of four people located in Chumteav Sok Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Hum Y., 35 years old and the mother of four children, is the group leader. Three of her children are attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Thoeurn Thorn, is a pig breeder who raises four pigs. Mrs. Hum Y. has a plot of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living. On her plantation, she now faces a small problem because her rice field is infertile, thus badly affecting her crops. To solve this problem, Mrs. Hum Y. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer to improve her field conditions and improve her crop growth.

All the members in the group have end-of-term loans and they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Andreya

texts.en:
Andreya has one child. She lives in Beregovo, Western Ukraine and sells different retail items in the local market. Her assortment is very diversified: household chemicals, beauty items, toys and different small necessities. Andreya is very cheerful and friendly. Her first goal is to please her customers, which has added a lot to the success of her business.

Andreya has been an entrepreneur for 2 years. Loans she has received and repaid from Nadiya Ukraine have also had a big part in the growth of her business. Presently, she has about 10,000 Grivnas in inventory. Monthly net profit is about 2,000 Grivnas. Today Andreya is requesting a loan of 5,000 Grivnas to increase assorted inventory. This financial assistance will help her increase her sales and grow her business as a result. Not only will it help Andreya get the necessary inventory and attract more customers, but it will help her meet the needs of her family and provide a better livelihood for them.

loans.use: Increase her assortment of inventory

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Before she met her husband, Rosalia Javier R. was a factory worker. She has also worked as a sales representative and as a housemaid. Her husband is very dedicated and determined to work hard to support his family.

She is thankful to ASHI for her first loan of PHP 5,000 (USD $125).  With that loan, she bought one hog as a starting point to a piggery.  She also wants to have a store where she can display and sell products like vegetables they harvest from their farm.

loans.use: Hog Fattening

loans.name: Nely

texts.es:
La señora Nely es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 31 años de edad, es soltera y no tiene hijos. 
Con el primer préstamo que recibió de S/.500, compró repuestos de electrodomésticos para vender en su tienda. Nos cuenta que está preparando la apertura de una nueva tienda en su domicilio y que tiene casi 2 años trabajando con el banco comunal. 
Con este préstamo de S/.1,200, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará más repuestos de electrodomésticos y terminará su nueva tienda.
Nely desea continuar trabajando para aumentar las ganancias de su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nely is a member of the Women United in Triumph (Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo) Community Bank in the district, province, and department of Puno. She is 31 years old, is single, and doesn’t have any children. With her first loan of 500 soles, she bought spare parts for electrical household appliances to sell in her store. She tells us that she is preparing to open a new store in her home. She has been working with the Community Bank for almost 2 years. With this loan of 1,200 soles, which will be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy more spare parts for electrical household appliances and will finish her new store. Nely wants to continue working to increase her earnings from her business.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy spare parts for electrical household appliances and will finish her new store

loans.name: Naheed Farzana M.shafee Group

texts.en:
Naheed Farzana Baji is a 42-year-old married lady and resides in a city named Multan, Pakistan. Her husband's name is M. Shafee and he works in a factory for a monthly wage. She is the mother of two kids: one son and one daughter. Her son works in a photocopier shop where he makes photocopies of documents. Naheed Baji is involved in a business making hair bands. It’s a high trend in women because they love to tie their hair in bands. Her daughter helps her in making the bands. Nabandsheed Baji has also embroidered dresses for the past 15 years. She plans to marry off her daughter when she gets the necessary amount. She is applying for a loan to buy cloth and colored thread to expand her embroidery and band-making business.

She is a group leader of some more women of her locality. Farman Baji wants a loan to buy paint boxes to resell. Mumtaz Baji wants a loan to buy warm clothes (sweaters and jackets) to resell. Farzana Baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her boutique.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for her embroidery business

loans.name: Tajudeen's Group

texts.en: Tajudeen crushes palm kernel. He has been in this business for a long time. He purchases the palm kernel and crushes it to sell to his customers. He needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more palm kernel to sell. He is 38 years old and married with a child. His wife is a tailor. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more palm kernel to crush

loans.name: Sophon

texts.en: Mrs. Sophon K. is a farmer in Ponley village in Takeo province. She has a small piece of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Moeurng Meng, helps her on the plantation. Although they try to work hard they still earn less income than they need to support the family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sophon K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to improve their living conditions after she sells the cow.  Mrs. Sophon K. is 53 years old and the mother of three children. Two of the children work in a garment factory and the youngest attends the local school. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Anonymous Group

texts.en:
Twenty-two people living I. Ta Daol Bei village I. Kandal province comprise this village bank group loan; they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Rat L. is the village bank president. She is employed I. a garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Touch Ty, is a fish seller I. the local market. Since his business is doing well, he wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Rat L. decided to ask for a loan to purchase more fish for her husband’s business to earn more income to support her family. She has three children; one is enrolled I. the local school and the others are too young to work or study. 

One member I. this group has an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal O. the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s maI. product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments O. time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% O. Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more fish

loans.name: Mgeni

texts.en:
Mgeni has been a clothes and home utensils seller in the Jang’ombe neighborhood of Zanzibar for four years. She belongs to the Mkorofi si mwenzetu group loan (Group code 2012).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $60. She works twelve hours a day at her business.  

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania, a Kiva field partner, so she can buy more items to expand her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to continue to grow her business.  

Mgeni is forty-seven years old, married, and has four children, aged twenty-seven, eighteen, sixteen and thirteen.

loans.use: To buy more items to expand her business.

loans.name: Oeur

texts.en:
A thatch cottage located in Pursat Province is where Mrs. Oeur S. lives with other family members since 1979. Mrs. S. is 62 and her husband, Mr. Choum, is age 57. Currently they both make their daily income by planting all kinds of crops.

The old couple has seven children, six of whom are married and live independently, and they are working in different jobs. S. humbly requests a loan as capital to support her business operation by buying rice seeds for growing.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Fatoumata Traoré a 54 ans mariée et mère de quatre   enfants (3 garçons et 1 fille) Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Wayerma II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Fatoumata Traoré est une secrétaire de formation, niveau Certificat d’Aptitude Professionnel (CAP). Après la fermeture d’une structure de l’état appelée   la  C.A.C il y a environ quinze ans, qui avait comme activité principale le stockage et commercialisation des céréales, cette  femme a repris en se lançant dans cette même activité de stockage et commercialisation des  céréales (maïs, mil, sorgho,arachides, fonio, etc.) qui marche bien avec elle. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  depuis maintenant quatre  ans. Après 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association MALI BOMO de Wayerma II), elle est actuellement à son quatrième prêt individuel de stockage et commercialisation. et tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 2 sacs de maïs, 3 sacs de Sorgho, 2 sacs d’arachide, 2 sacs de fonio, 4 sacs de mil, etc. Elle s’approvisionne à Zégoua et dans les localités environnantes de Sikasso avant de les stocker  dans son magasin situé au marché de son quartier afin de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des chefs de famille.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Fatoumata Traoré, age 54, is married and the mother of four children (3 boys and 1 girl). She resides with her husband and their children in Wayerma II, a working-class district of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She is a secretary by training, achieving the Certificat d’Aptitude Professionnel (CAP). After the closure of a state organization called C.A.C. about 15 years ago that use to stock and to market grains, this women picked up again by getting started in this same business of stocking and marketing grains (corn, millet, sorghum, peanuts, fonio, etc.), which is going well for her. Concerned about doing better in satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago now. After three solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association in her area (Association MALI BOMO de Wayerma II), she is now on her fourth individual loan for stocking and marketing. All of her preceding loans have been correctly repaid. With this loan, she intends to buy two sacks of corn, three sacks of sorghum, two sacks of peanuts, two sacks of fonio, four sacks of millet, etc. Supplies of these goods are gotten in Zégoua and in towns surrounding Sikasso. The goods are then stocked in her store located at the marketplace in her district in order to be resold at the retail level. Customers are generally the heads of households. She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help with family expenses, to make loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grains (millet, corn, peanuts, sorghum, etc.)

loans.name: Flery

texts.en:
Flery V. is from Antipolo, the capital city of the Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is married to Elisse V., who is 59 and her partner in her business. Flery is the mother of two sons and two daughters. The eldest child, Samuel, is a 31-year old high-school graduate, while the youngest, Flerry Fe, is 20 and a college graduate.

In the year 2000, Flery joined ASHI (Ahon Sa hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since then, she has had access to capital for her business. They utilized their loans as capital for the selling of balot (boiled chicken eggs that have incubated for 18 days) in the city. Local folks are fond of buying balot during evening time while relaxing or during recreation. Since the demand for balot is consistent, the business is successful.

Now on her 13th loan, she is requesting 30,000 pesos as additional capital for the selling of balot and the remaining amount will be used to pay for a videoke machine (a machine used for recreation in which you sing on a television screen with sound, somewhat like Magic Sing) as her secondary business. This machine will be rented out to interested individuals. Singing videoke is one of the most common relaxation strategies of Filipinos. Flery is hopeful that her businesses will grow and give them enough profits.

She dreams of having a house and a lot of her own. And in the near future, she is looking forward to buying a rickshaw to more easily transport her balot.

loans.use: Additional capital for "balot" selling and to pay for a videoke machine

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene B., a 30-year-old native of Sayon, Sta. Josefa, has always dreamed of owning another parcel of land to expand her present rice farming business. This is where the family gets additional income for their food supply, school obligations for their three children, and some money to set aside as savings.

Arlene joined the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI) because, aside from the services this institution is offering, she also learns many things about business through CEVI’s free training and seminars.

Presently, Arlene is asking for a loan from CEVI amounting to Php 15,000.00. This sum will be used as additional capital for her business, particularly in purchasing seed and other farming necessities.

loans.use: To buy seed and other farming necessities

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie C. is just 23 years old and a mother of two children. She wants to save funds for the future education of her children by running her simple vending business in their village at Barangay Sta. Barbara Ventro Ilagan, Isabela. For five years of doing her business, her income has remained almost the same because there has been no improvement taking place in her vending because of lack of financial working capital. That’s why she is asking for a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP 8,000.

The loan will be of big help to be able to purchase additional products for her store. Marie has been dreaming of growing her business, to have a complete inventory and her own permanent store someday. She hopes that through her business, she will be able to attain her dreams in life.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Nova

texts.en:
Nova O. is 39 years old, married with 7 children ranging from school age to young adults. Nova's family lives in Hacienda San Jose 2, Brgy. Luna, Cadiz City, in the province of Negros Occidental.

Nova owns and operates a "sari-sari" store - the Filipino equivalent of the neighborhood General store. She opened the store soon after she became a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005. Now, her General Store earns PHP 5,000.00 per month for the O. family.

Nova has invested all of her previous loans to expand her General Store so that she could offer a wider variety of goods to her neighbors and to stay ahead of her competitors. 

For this, her 7th loan cycle, Nova is borrowing PHP 19,500 to again invest in her General Store in the hope that if she offers a wider variety than her competitors, her customers will stay loyal to her. Her business acumen is obvious in that for the past four years, her choices have always paid back for her and her family.

Erna is determined to work hard and build her business so that her family's financial standing will be on stable ground that can provide a good life for her and her family.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL CAPITAL FOR HER GENERAL STORE

loans.name: Aurora

texts.es:
La señora Aurora es socia del Banco Comunal “21 D. Febrero”, en el distrito D. D. Ilave, provincia D. El Collao, en el departamento D. Puno, ella tiene 41 años D. edad, es casada y madre D. 6 hijos, ella pudo estudiar la educación primaria incompleta, vive en el Barrio D. Lacaya.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace 2 años, su primer préstamo fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, dinero que utilizó para la compra D. abarrotes.

Actualmente, ella requiere un préstamo D. S/. 700.00 nuevos soles, este préstamo le servirá para poder comprar papa, ocas, quinua, etc. Estos productos D. la región los venD. en las ferias D. Ilave 

Su deseo es comprarse un carro y seguir trabajando.

A ella le gustan los ahorros y la forma D. trabajar.
texts.en:
Sra. Aurora is a member of the Communal Bank “21 D. Febrero” (February 21st), which is located in the District of Ilave, El Collao Province, Department of Puno. She is 41 years old, married, and the mother of 6 children. Sra. Aurora did not finish elementary school. She lives in the neighborhood of Lacaya. For the past 2 years, she has been working with Manuela Ramos. Her first loan of 300 soles was used to purchase groceries. She is now requesting a loan of 700 soles to purchase potatoes, geese, quinoa, and other items. She plans to sell these regional products at the fairs in Illave. Sra. Aurora hopes to buy a car and keep working. She enjoys her savings and her line of work.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase potatoes, geese, quinoa, etc.

loans.name: Rodelma

texts.en: Rodelma D. is from the village of Puntod Upper, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Rodelma owns and operates a sari-sari or general store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, etc., to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month. In 2007, Rodelma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rodelma is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fifth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kemmy

texts.en:
Kemmy is a 27-year-old mother of two who operates a kerosene pump in Nairobi. She previously operated a retail shop before she went into selling kerosene one year ago. She is requesting a first loan of Kes. 50,000 to enable her to buy a fuel pump. She hopes to expand her business into a fueling station, to buy rental units and to educate her children. Kemmy describes herself as hardworking, patient and focused.



About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy a fuel pump

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo has been interested in the restaurant business for some time, having done apprenticeships at multiple coffee shops. At the beginning of this year, he and his business partner, Jarrod, jointly purchased their first cafe. They located themselves across the street from a train station, taking note that, while the area did have a few coffee shop chain stores, they didn't offer the "coffee house" vibe that Alfredo and Jarrod planned to bring to the neighborhood, with specialty drinks and great live music.

As of now, Alfredo and Jarrod are breaking even with their business that specializes in coffee, tea, pastries, and smoothies (a blended, chilled beverage made from fresh fruit or vegetables). They have some regulars and their foot traffic is steadily increasing, but they feel they could really take their business to the next level with some advertising in print media, on television, and through direct mail postcards that would help increase their visibility.

By drawing more people to their shop, they hope to grow their cafe and turn it into a place that neighborhood patrons love to frequent as a unique place not only to get a great cup of coffee but also to catch local live music acts.

loans.use: To pay for advertising to increase their visibility

loans.name: Rasool 16 Group

texts.en:
Ghulam Rasool wants to receive a loan for a car parts shop to buy the essential materials. Shanaz wants to take out a loan for her husband’s general store to complete his stock. Seema wants to take out a loan for her tailoring business in order to buy a new sewing machine, because she has lots of problems with the old one.

This is the Rasool 16 Group. Ghulam Rasool is the group leader. The three members have requested a group loan of 42,000 afghanis. Finally, they would like to thank the Kiva lenders a lot.

loans.use: To buy requirements for a car parts shop

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
According to Marites R., “Patience and hard work are the best character traits that should be developed when engaged in business." She has a vegetable plantation beside their house and, being a vegetable vendor for almost five years, she has been very hardworking to support her family. She earns Php 200 daily. Aside from that, she also has a laundry business sometimes to generate extra income.

However, Marites’ income is not good enough to provide for their necessities so she decided to obtain a loan of Php 4,000 to have additional capital to improve her vending business.

Marites is married to Gavino R., a farmer. They have three children: Aries, 18, in college level; Ruel, 16, a first-year college student; and Gabriel, 3 years old. They are presently living in the friendly village of Sta. Maria, Alicia, Isabela.

Marites hopes that Kiva lenders will grant her loan immediately, to enable her to have continuous development in her business.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her vegetable vending business

loans.name: Eunice Awour

texts.en: Eunice is twenty-five years old, married and mother to two daughters. She runs a hardware business where she sells screws, nails, light bulbs and wires to walk-ins and frequent customers. She currently has one employee. Her business challenge is the fluctuating demand. She is using the loan proceeds of KES 40,000 to increase stock for the hardware store. In future, she wants to be a wholesaler and to further educate her children. Eunice describes herself as hardworking, friendly and honest.

loans.use: To buy hardware items such as, screws, lightbulbs, cables and nails.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Benkadi sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans, 5 enfants et vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Bougoula Hameau un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur sixième  prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts précédents se sont bien dénoués. 
Elles font  vente  d’huiles alimentaires, de plats alimentaires (riz préparé), des savons et des condiments alimentaires.
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 8 bidons d’huiles alimentaires, 3 sacs de 100kg de graines de riz, 12 colis de condiments alimentaires et 14 cartons de savons modernes. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent au marché de (Bougoula Hameau), à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 47.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles espèrent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  subvenir davantage aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group's seven members are primarily married women who are on average 37 years old, have an average number of five children, and mostly live in polygamous families in Bougoula Hameau. This is a village in the Sikasso municipality, the third largest administrative region of Mali. They are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance association in order to satisfy the demands of their customers, and are on their sixth consecutive loan. All previous loans have been dealt with successfully. They sell cooking oils, pre-prepared dishes (such as pre-prepared rice), soap and condiments. They would use their new loan to buy eight drums of cooking oil, three 100kg sacks of rice, twelve parcels of condiments, and 14 boxes of local soap. They source their goods from the large Sikasso town market and its neighbouring villages. They sell their goods through cash or credit sales at the Bougoula Hameau market and through home visits. Their customers are both male and female. They envisage making an average monthly profit of 47.500 FCFA; part of this would be put aside for family savings and needs, and the rest would be reinvested in business activities. The women hope to increase their capital in order to satisfy their customers and to meet the demands of their families.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods.

loans.name: Paula Pedro

texts.pt:
Paula Pedro B. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província do mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique, tem 28 anos de idade, casada mãe de 1 filho de 8 anos de idade que vai a escola. Fez 10ª classe, parou porque na altura esteve grávida e sofreu uma operação durante o parto, obrigando lhe parar durante longo período. Vive na casa própria com a sua família, sustenta sua irmã que vive com ela e de vez enquanto ajuda seus pais na cidade de Maputo em despesas alimentares.

Saiu da cidade de Maputo para Boane em 1998 com o seu esposo para iniciar um novo lar. Tem um negocio próprio desde 2004, conta com um empregado e faz em media cerca de 8 horas por dia. Aprendeu esta actividade com a sua tia que fazia o negócio na cidade de Maputo desde 1989,onde vende mais refeições, humburguers, e refrescos. Consegue um rendimento de cerca de 9.000.00mt por mes, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária e através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa) mensal. 

Já teve empréstimos na cooperativa de crédito THUMA, por varias insatisfações decidiu não continuar. Conheceu a Hluvuku através da sua amiga que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (frangos, peixe, carne, refrigerantes, cervejas, vinhos e outras bebidas alcoólicas) para aumentar a quantidade e diversificar a sua mercadoria. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 6.000.00mt e 7.000.00mt ambos para mesma actividade.

Um dos sonhos é comprar uma carinha basculante para carregar areia e pedra para a comercialização.  
Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para o comércio e terminar a sua obra.
texts.en:
Paula Pedro B. was born in Maputo, south of Mozambique. She is 28 years old, married and the mother of a 8 year old boy who goes to school. She studied until 10th grade but had to drop school because she got pregnant and had to had a surgery during her pregnancy. She lives in her own house with her family and a sister who lives with them. She also helps her parents who still live in Maputo with money for food. She left Maputo to start a new life in Boane with her husband in 1998. She has had her own business since 2004, where she sells meals, burgers and refreshments. She makes around 9.000,00MT (U$290) per month, that she uses to support her household and put some away in a savings account. She has had other loans with the credit cooperative THUMA but was unsatisfied with them. She found out about Hluvuku through a friend who's also a client. This is her third loan in the amount of 10.000,00MT (U$350) that she'll use to buy more food products (chicken, fish, meat, soft drinks, beer, wine and other alcoholic beverages) to diversify what she sells and improve her business. Her other loans were for the same purpose. One of Paula's dreams is to buy a tilting carriage in order to carry sand and rocks and sell it around. In the future she would like to get more loans in order to improve her business and finish building her house.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products

loans.name: Tep

texts.en: Tep S., 45, is married with four children who are no longer in school. Two of them are employed and work in restaurant, while the other two assist her with her business. She owns a small shop in her home where she sells food to her nearby neighbors. In the morning she sells porridge and in the evening she sells beef soup. She is married to Pheng, 37, a military policeman. Tep S. will use her loan to purchase a motorcycle for her family's transportation needs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Gundsambuu

texts.en:
Gundsambuu is 20 years old and lives with his mother and two younger brothers in the Zavhan province in Mongolia. He and his family live in a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent called “ger.” His mother had a very serious car accident and became handicapped. She needs care every single day. His mother receives 54,000 tugrugs (about $38) of allowances per month, which is too low for a living. 

Gundsambuu operates a wooden product making business with the help of his younger brother in his town. He started his business in 2007 after his high school graduation. He made his decision based on his difficult life of taking care of his mother and paying for his brothers' education. He makes all kinds of furniture using black wood and cedar wood, which makes the wooden products very strong and hard. In 2009 he began to operate his own wooden product making business using his tools purchased from China. 

He has been quite successful in conducting his business and has established a strong customer base. He is very hardworking and always looks for ways to grow his business. With his business earnings, he was able to buy a new cover for his ger, which enabled his home to be more warm than before. For the future, Altansukh plans to expand and improve his business in order to have enough treatment money for his mother. He truly wants his mother to stand by using a walking stick.  

He is requesting a 500,000 tugrug loan to purchase cedar wood and other materials used to make his products.

loans.use: To purchase cedar wood and other materials

loans.name: Feliza

texts.en:
Feliza A. is from the village of Calaocan in the Alicia municipality of Isabela Province. She is 59 years old. Feliza is widowed and has three grown children. To make a living, Feliza owns and operates a vegetable stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables in the local community. Feliza has been engaged in her business for over 10 years, and she earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Feliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Feliza is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Feliza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support members of her extended family.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Grupo Sicalbe 2 Group

texts.es: Son un grupo de personas que viven a 60 kilometros de la ciudad. Se han reunidos para un proyecto de Mini riego, ya que se dedican a la siembra de tomates, cuentan con experiencia alrededor de 5 años como grupo, ya que es un producto calificados su produccion se vendidos en paises de Centro America. El agua que utilizan proviene de nacimientos de las montañas del mismo lugar de Momostenango, ellos residen en la Aldea Xequemeyá, actualmente cuentan con el proyecto de agua de miniriego, pero no tienen accesos a financiamiento debido a que son de escasos recursos economicos. Es la primera vez que solicitan su prestamo en ASDIR. De acuerdo al estudio realizado se verifico la actividad economicas y los terrenos de cultivo de tomate con que cuentan. Por esta razón se considera al momento de incrementar su capital de agricultura hará que las personas aumenten sus cosechas, y de esa manera obtener mejores ingresos economicos, de la misma manera mejorará sus condiciones de vida, como también ayudarán a las personas del lugar a que los productos que venden sean mas baratos que en el mercado del lugar.
texts.en:
This group of people lives 60 miles away from the city. They have joined together to work on a Micro-irrigation system since they grow tomatoes. They count on the 5 years of experience they have earned since their product is well-known and sold throughout Central America. The water they use comes from the Momostenango mountains. They live in the small village of Xeqeumayá. Currently they depend on the Micro-irrigation system but lack the funding due to scarce economic resources. This is the first time they request a loan from ASDIR. According to the study undertaken, the financial activities of the borrowers and the land they use for planting tomatoes, were verified. This is why they consider this the right time to increase their funds. This will help build up their crops to earn more, improve their standards of living, and sell their product at a lower price than the local market.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Micro-irrigation

loans.name: Sichat

texts.en: Sichat, age 38, is single and lives with her brother and elderly father on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She has been a silk weaver for more than 20 years. She sells her finished products to middleman in the village, who then sell the products in Phnom Penh market. Sichat has borrowed through Kiva one time already, and she now is asking for another loan in the amount of $200 to purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.name: Mehnaz's Group

texts.en:
Mehnaz is a citizen of a city named Borewala a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. She is a very hard working lady. She operates an embroider clothes business to generate income. Her income allows her to pay for the utilities but she also saves a part for the rainy days.

Her husband name is M. A. operates a timber selling business. He has been selling it for the back 10 years. He earns not only money but the respect as well. All of his customers come to him for purchasing because of his good dealing. 

Mehnaz is applying for a loan to buy timbers in bulk to expand her husband’s timber selling business.

loans.use: To buy timbers to sell

loans.name: Kavumbi

texts.en: Kavumbi is married to a mason and has four girls and one boy. Only two of her children were able to attend school. Kavumbi sells cassavas, coconuts, and brooms. She has been in this business for 10 years and has no other sources of income. She sells her products wholesale door to door. Her customers are retailers and food vendors. Her greatest challenge is that her customers don't always make their payments. She aspires to be a dairy farmer and with the ksh. 30,000, loan she wants to purchase a dairy cow and pay for brooms and coconuts in advance. Kavumbi owns her home but does not have electricity or running water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. She hopes to lift her living standard and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow, coconuts, brooms

loans.name: Ma. Rolenda

texts.en:
Ma. Rolenda L. is from the village of Balbagon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 35 years old. Ma. Rolenda is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Rolenda owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Ma. Rolenda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ma. Rolenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Rolenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Ma. Rolenda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Ma. Rolenda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Carla

texts.es:
La señora Carla vive en ella sola en alquiler en  la zona 14 de septiembre de la ciudad de La Paz,, sus padres viven en Santa Cruz. La actividad que ella realiza es la venta de comida en un restaurante en su mismo domicilio.

 El crédito que solicita es para comprar víveres e insumos para los almuerzos que ella vende, pues esta actividad es su única fuente de ingresos que usa para su manutención.

Esta es la primera vez que solicita un préstamo de Impro y  por el carácter social del mismo nos parece que lo podemos canalizar a través de Ki
texts.en:
Sra. Carla lives alone in a rental property in the September 14th district of the city of La Paz. Her parents live in Santa Cruz. She sells food from a restaurant she manages out of her home.

The loan she is requesting will be used to buy food and supplies for preparing lunches that she sells. This activity is her only source of income by which she supports herself.

Carla is applying for her first loan with IMPRO. Based on her social character, it is evident that her loan request can be channeled through Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for her small restaurant

loans.name: Sègodo

texts.fr: H. Sègodo est né le 14 Décembre 1981 et vit depuis deux ans au quartier Avotrou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Sègodo n’est pas encore marié.
